Knowledge Point: The position as the leftmost non-verb constituent in a sentence defines the theme in Mauwake. It may be an argument or a peripheral clause participant. When a sentence -- or the first clause in a multi-clause sentence -- consists of a verb alone, there is no theme in the sense adopted here. When the theme is an argument, it introduces what the sentence is about \REF{ex:9:x1908}. When it is not an argument but a peripheral clause participant, it provides a circumstancial setting for the sentence, most commonly a locative or temporal setting \REF{ex:9:x1698}. A theme forms one intonation contour with the rest of the clause.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} \textbf{owow} \textbf{mua=ke} wilkar wia muf-em-ik-om-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM village man=CF cart 3p.ACC pull-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `The village men pulled carts for them.'
Content 2: \gll Ne \textbf{fraide=pa} maapora puk-o-k, urera. | \gls ADD Friday=LOC party burst-PA-3s afternoon | \glt `And on Friday the party started, in the afternoon.'

Knowledge Point: When the theme coincides with the subject/topic \REF{ex:9:x1908}, the clause has the default word order. But when another argument is the theme, it takes the initial position, and if there is also a subject \textsc{np} in the same clause, it follows the theme \textsc{np} \REF{ex:9:x1473}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} \textbf{owow} \textbf{mua=ke} wilkar wia muf-em-ik-om-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM village man=CF cart 3p.ACC pull-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `The village men pulled carts for them.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{yar}\textsubscript{O} i\textsubscript{S} uruf-am-ik-omkun o koora=pa pok-ap ik-ua. | \gls 1p.UNM 1s/p.brother.in.law 1p.UNM see-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS 3s.UNM house=LOC sit.down-SS.SEQ be-PA.3s | \glt `Our brother-in-law, as we are seeing him, is sitting in his house.' (Lit: `Our brother-in-law we are seeing and he is sitting in his house.')

Knowledge Point: The sentence \REF{ex:9:x1701} is from the middle of a description about the arrival of the Japanese troops, and the goods that they brought are only mentioned in this one sentence, and the theme is neither the subject nor the topic.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Maa} \textbf{unowa}\textsubscript{O} ifer aasa=ke p-urup-eya miiw-aasa=ke fan p-ir-am-ik-ua. | \gls thing many sea canoe=CF BPX-ascend-2/3s.DS land-canoe=CF here BPX-come-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `Many things were brought up (to the coast) by ships and brought here by trucks.'

Knowledge Point: In a text about a school party, dancing is first mentioned in a final verb, and then the dance becomes the theme for the following sentence \REF{ex:9:x1702}:
Content 1: \gll Naap ik-ok wi Saramun=ke wiisa uf-e-mik. \textbf{Uf-owa} \textbf{eliwa}\textsubscript{O} i wiar uruf-a-mik. | \gls thus be-SS 3p.UNM Saramun=CF dance.name dance-PA-1/3p dance-NMZ good 1p.UNM 3.DAT see-PA-1/3p | \glt `Then the Saramun people danced wiisa. It was a good dance we saw from them.'

Knowledge Point: Very commonly, the subject only shows in the verbal suffixation, and the theme position is taken either by an object -- which may or may not be a topic -- or by an adverbial phrase. In \REF{ex:9:x1909} the theme \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{auwa ame} `father and the others' becomes a topic that continues for the next five clauses, whereas the themes of \REF{ex:9:x1910} and \REF{ex:9:x1911} do not become topics and are not mentioned any more. (In the free translation it is often not possible to reflect the theme naturally.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Auwa} \textbf{ame} wia maak-eya res aaw-ep merena ifa keraw-a-k nain puuk-a-mik. | \gls 1s/p.father ASSOC 3p.ACC tell-2/3s.DS razor take-SS.SEQ leg snake bite-PA-3s that1 cut-PA-1/3p | \glt `He told my father and the others, and they took a razor and made a cut into the leg that the snake had bitten.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Maa} \textbf{en-owa} nopa-yiaw-ep wailal-ep naap ma-e-mik... | \gls thing eat-NMZ search-move.around-SS.SEQ hunger-SS.SEQ thus say-PA-1/3p | \glt `They searched around for food and were hungry and said like that{\dots}'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Emeria} naap wia aruf-i-nen na-ep on-a-k. | \gls woman thus 3p.ACC hit-NP-FU.1s say/think-SS.SEQ do-PA-3s | \glt `He tried to hit the women like that.'

Knowledge Point: In a tail-head linkage construction (\sectref{sec:8.2.3.5}) the final verb of a sentence is repeated in the beginning of the following sentence, but in a medial form. An argument \REF{ex:9:x1912}, \REF{ex:9:x1913}, or occasionally a peripheral \REF{ex:9:x1914}, \REF{ex:9:x1915}, from the final clause may be picked as the theme of the new sentence.
Content 1: \gll Owowa or-op, wailal-ep akia ik-e-k. \textbf{Akia} ik-ep en-em-ik-ok{\dots} | \gls village descend-SS.SEQ hunger-SS.SEQ banana roast-PA-3s banana roast-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM-be-SS | \glt `He came down to the village, was hungry, and roasted bananas. He roasted bananas and was eating them and {\dots}'
Content 2: \gll Aria, wi kiiriw neeke {\O} miiw-aasa um-o-k. \textbf{Miiw-a}\textbf{asa} um-eya miiw-aasa nain on-am-ika-iwkin... | \gls alright 3p.UNM again there.CF {\O} land-canoe die-PA-3s land-canoe die-2/3s.DS land-canoe that1 do-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS | \glt `Alright, again when they (were) there the truck broke down (lit: died). The truck broke down, and while they were working on the truck{\dots}'
Content 3: \gll Yaki-ep weeser-eya owowa urup-e-mik. \textbf{Owowa} urup-ep o koora ikiw-o-k. | \gls bathe-SS.SEQ finish-2/3s.DS village ascend-PA-1/3p village ascend-SS.SEQ 3s.UNM house go-PA-3s | \glt `They bathed and when it was finished they came up to the village. They came to the village and he went into the house.'

Knowledge Point: When the theme position is taken by a locative \REF{ex:9:x1699} or temporal \REF{ex:9:x1916} adverbial phrase, it normally gives a setting for the the whole sentence:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Eka} \textbf{mamaiya} \textbf{akena} i yoowa me aaw-i-yen. | \gls river close very 1p.UNM hot not get-NP-FU.1p | \glt `Very close to the river we won't get hot.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikoka} \textbf{kuisow} miiw-aasa=ke karu-eya ku-ku-ep or-om-ik-ua. | \gls later one land-canoe=CF run-2/3s.DS RDP-break-SS.SEQ descend-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `Straight away when the trucks ran (over them) they kept breaking and falling down.'

Knowledge Point: But in \REF{ex:9:x1703}, the first temporal phrase is a setting for only the first clause, and the final clause has another temporal phrase. Also, in the second sentence the object is both a new topic (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}) and fronted as the theme before the temporal adverbial. In neutral constituent order, a temporal adverbial precedes the object.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Uura} \textbf{feenap} \textbf{nain} i me in-em-ik-e-mik, amirika maa me en-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Maa} uura uup-ep en-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls night like.this that1 1p.UNM not sleep-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p day food not eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p food night cook-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `On nights like this we did not sleep, in the daytime we did not eat food. The food we used to cook and eat at night.'

Knowledge Point: Other adverbial phrases may also be used in the theme position to provide a circumstantial setting \REF{ex:9:x1917}, \REF{ex:9:x1918}. In particular, the deictic manner adverbial \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus, like that' is relatively common.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Naap} maak-iwkin naap ik-ua. \textbf{Naap} ik-ok uruf-am-ika-iwkin wia. | \gls thus tell-2/3p.DS thus be-PA.3s thus be-SS see-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS no | \glt `Like that they told him and like that he was. Like that he was and they watched him, but no (he did not get better).'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wiena} \textbf{merena} \textbf{ne} \textbf{wapen=iw} era akup-ami owowa ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN foot ADD hand=INST road search-SS.SIM village go-PA-1/3p | \glt `With their feet and hands they searched the road and went to the village.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:x1704}, the left-dislocated theme consists of a relative clause where the antecedent noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{soo} `fish trap' has been deleted:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There can be more than one dislocated theme for the same clause. In \REF{ex:9:x1700}, there are two dislocated themes -- a temporal and a locative phrase -- plus a clause-internal theme \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moma} `taro', which is the syntactic object of the clause:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Iiriw}, \textbf{owow(a)} \textbf{oko} \textbf{mua} \textbf{manina}, moma waaya=ke anane wiar en-ow(a)=iw ika-i-ya. | \gls earlier village other man garden taro pig=CF always 3.DAT eat-NMZ=INST be-NP-PR.3s | \glt `Earlier, (in) the garden of a man from another village, his taro was always being eaten by a pig.'

Knowledge Point: Even when a new topic is introduced for the first time, it is often definite,\footnote{Definiteness is not an obligatory category in Mauwake. A \textsc{np} may be specifically marked as definite or indefinite when this feature is considered important enough, but often it is left unspecified.} identifiable to the addressee: a personal pronoun \REF{ex:9:x1663}, a proper name \REF{ex:9:x1664} or a relationship term \REF{ex:9:x1665}, or a noun phrase \REF{ex:9:x1667}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Aria \textbf{yena} \textbf{mua} pun ... iirar-iwkin owowa ekap-o-k. | \gls alright 1s.GEN man also ... remove-2/3p.DS village come-PA-3s | \glt `Alright they also dismissed my husband {\dots} and he came to the village.'
Content 4: \gll Iiriw \textbf{wi} \textbf{mua} \textbf{iperowa=ke} feenap ma-em-ik-e-mik, emeria=ke osaiwa ar-e-mik. | \gls earlier 3p.UNM man middle.aged=CF like.this say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p woman=CF bird.of.paradise become-PA-1/3p | \glt `Earlier the elders kept telling this story that women had changed into birds of paradise.'

Knowledge Point: When a potential topic is introduced, it is indefinite -- the addressee is not expected to be able to identify it -- and one of the following strategies is used. The new topic may first be an object in a clause before becoming the subject in the following clause. \REF{ex:9:x1703} is repeated here as \REF{ex:9:x1668}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Uura} \textbf{feenap} \textbf{nain} i me in-em-ik-e-mik, amirika maa me en-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Maa} uura uup-ep en-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls night like.this that1 1p.UNM not sleep-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p day food not eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p food night cook-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `On nights like this we did not sleep, in the daytime we did not eat food. The food we used to cook and eat at night.'
Content 2: \gll Uura feenap nain i me in-em-ik-e-mik, amirika \textbf{maa} me en-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Maa} uura uup-ep en-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls night like.this that1 1p.UNM not sleep-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p noon food not eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p food night cook-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM.be-PA-1/3p | \glt `On nights like this we did not sleep, at noon we did not eat food. Food we used to cook and eat at night.'

Knowledge Point: % Replace \REF{ex:9:x1668} with \REF{ex:9:x1703 ? The final text should read: (15) is repeated here:
Content 1: \gll Uura feenap nain i me in-em-ik-e-mik, amirika \textbf{maa} me en-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Maa} uura uup-ep en-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls night like.this that1 1p.UNM not sleep-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p noon food not eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p food night cook-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM.be-PA-1/3p | \glt `On nights like this we did not sleep, at noon we did not eat food. Food we used to cook and eat at night.'

Knowledge Point: Most commonly, the new topic is already a subject in the clause where it is introduced, and the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} is either modified with the indefinite \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oko} `other' \REF{ex:9:x1669} or marked by the neutral focus clitic \textit{-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ko}} \REF{ex:9:x1670}, which also has its origin in \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oko}. Occasionally both of them occur on the same \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} \REF{ex:9:x1671}.
Content 1: \gll Iiriw Malala suule maneka \textbf{uuw-owa} \textbf{mua} \textbf{oko} unuma Kila. | \gls earlier Malala school big work-NMZ man other name Kila | \glt `Earlier there was a workman at the big Malala school whose name was Kila.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Emer(a)} \textbf{en-ow(a)} \textbf{mua=ko} emeria fan aaw-o-k. | \gls sago eat-NMZ man=NF woman here take-PA-3s | \glt `A Sepik man married a wife here.'
Content 3: \gll Iiriw akena \textbf{mua} \textbf{oko=ko} fura aaw-ep koka iw-a-k. | \gls earlier very man other=NF knife take-SS.SEQ jungle go-PA-3s | \glt `Long ago a man took a knife and went into the jungle.'

Knowledge Point: \noindent The indefinite \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} may even have contrastive focus marking \REF{ex:9:x1666}:
Content 1: \gll Pika ifara mufe-wiaw-ik-ok \textbf{ifa} \textbf{maneka=ke} siowa wiar aaw-o-k. | \gls fence vine pull-move.around-be-SS snake big=CF dog 3.DAT take-PA-3s | \glt `As he was pulling around vines for the fence, a big snake grabbed his dog.'

Knowledge Point: Existential clauses, which \citet[741]{Givon1990} mentions as one of the major strategies for introducing important topics, are possible but not very commonly employed for this function in Mauwake \REF{ex:9:x1672}. Note that the neutral focus clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ko} is also present.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Iiriw} \textbf{mua} \textbf{iperowa=ko} nan Wakoruma owowa=pa ik-ua. | \gls earlier man middle.aged=NF there Wakoruma village=LOC be-PA.3s | \glt `Earlier there was a middle-aged man in Wakoruma village.'

Knowledge Point: When a potential topic, which is indefinite when first introduced, becomes established the next mention is often made with a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} marked as definite by the distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that'. The sentence following \REF{ex:9:x1672} in the text is \REF{ex:9:x1673}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Iiriw} \textbf{mua} \textbf{iperowa=ko} nan Wakoruma owowa=pa ik-ua. | \gls earlier man middle.aged=NF there Wakoruma village=LOC be-PA.3s | \glt `Earlier there was a middle-aged man in Wakoruma village.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{nain} emeria ne muuka wiipa marew. | \gls man that1 woman ADD son daughter no(ne). | \glt `The man had no wife or children.'

Knowledge Point: Another possibility is the mere subject marking on the verb: sentence \REF{ex:9:x1674} below is continuation to the sentence \REF{ex:9:x1670} above.
Content 1: \gll Ne manina ikiw-o-\textbf{k}. | \gls ADD garden go-PA-3s. | \glt `And he went to the garden.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Emer(a)} \textbf{en-ow(a)} \textbf{mua=ko} emeria fan aaw-o-k. | \gls sago eat-NMZ man=NF woman here take-PA-3s | \glt `A Sepik man married a wife here.'

Knowledge Point: When the topic is already definite when introduced, it is possible to make a second mention with a personal pronoun \REF{ex:9:x1919}.\footnote{This whole story is Text \ref{app:2:uncle} in the Appendix.}
Content 1: \gll Yena yaiya Tup ifa ku-o-k nain opaimika ma-i-yem. Ae, \textbf{o} fiker(a) gone urup-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN 1s/p.uncle Tup snake bite-PA-3s that1 talk say-NP-PR.1s yes 3s.UNM kunai.grass middle ascend-PA-3s | \glt `I tell a story about that when my uncle Tup was bitten by a snake. Yes, he went up to the middle of the kunai grass (area).'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:x1868} the personal pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wi} `they' in the second sentence refers to the ``weria-relatives'' (see \sectref{sec:1.3.6}), introduced as the object in the preceding sentence; a mere verbal suffix would indicate continuation with the old topic, i.e. those who sent the message.
Content 1: \gll Wiena mua weria ... opaimika wia sesek-omak-e-mik. Ne \textbf{wi} ekap-e-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN man planting.stick ... talk 3p.ACC send-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p ADD 3p.UNM come-PA-1/3p | \glt `They\textsubscript{i} sent word to their\textsubscript{i} many weria-relatives\textsubscript{j}. And they\textsubscript{j} came.'

Knowledge Point: More commonly the topic, once established, is maintained as a continuing topic without an overt \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} or a pronoun, only via subject marking on the verb. This minimal marking conforms to \citegen[67]{Givon1983} claim that the heaviness of the topic marking is in inverse relation to topic continuity/predictability. The following example \REF{ex:9:x1675} is a section of a text where \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sawur} `spirits', introduced earlier, think that there is a boy on the bed they are carrying, but the boy has already escaped. The reference to the spirits is only made by medial and final verb suffixes.
Content 1: \gll Ne aria, samapora oram akua aaw-\textbf{ep} ikiw-e-\textbf{mik}. Ikiw-\textbf{ep} wiena owowa=pa uruf-a-\textbf{mik}=na weetak, samapora muutiw akua aaw-e-\textbf{mik}. Aria nainiw kir-e-\textbf{mik}. Kir-\textbf{ep} ekap-em-ika-\textbf{iwkin} epa wiim-o-k. | \gls ADD alright, bed just shoulder take-SS.SEQ go-PA-1/3p go-SS.SEQ 3p.GEN village=LOC see-PA-1/3p=TP no bed only shoulder take-PA-1/3p alright again turn-PA-1/3p turn-SS.SEQ come-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS place dawn-PA-3s | \glt `Alright, they carried just the bed and went. They went and in their village they looked but (to their surprise) they only carried the bed. Alright they turned back again. They turned and as they were coming, it dawned.'

Knowledge Point: The switch-reference system (§\sectref{sec:3.8.3.5}, \ref{sec:8.2.3}) together with the person/number marking in the finite verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.4}) can easily keep track of two active topics alternating with each other \REF{ex:9:x1676}.
Content 1: \gll O iiwawun samor aaw-o-k. Ne nan ik-e-\textbf{mik}. Nan ik-\textbf{ok} ik-\textbf{ok} neeke pu-o-\textbf{k}. Neeke pu-\textbf{eya} oram akua aaw-e-\textbf{mik}. | \gls 3s.UNM altogether badly get-PA-3s ADD there be-PA-1/3p there be-SS be-SS there.CF die-PA-3s. there.CF die-2/3s.DS just shoulder take-PA-1/3p | \glt `He got really bad. They stayed and stayed there and he died there. He died there and they just carried him on their shoulders.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:x1676} one of the topics is in the singular, the other in the plural. But in (3.\ref{ex:3:x357}), repeated below as \REF{ex:9:x1920}, there are two third person singular topics alternating, with only the verbal marking to indicate who is doing what:
Content 1: \gll O iiwawun samor aaw-o-k. Ne nan ik-e-\textbf{mik}. Nan ik-\textbf{ok} ik-\textbf{ok} neeke pu-o-\textbf{k}. Neeke pu-\textbf{eya} oram akua aaw-e-\textbf{mik}. | \gls 3s.UNM altogether badly get-PA-3s ADD there be-PA-1/3p there be-SS be-SS there.CF die-PA-3s. there.CF die-2/3s.DS just shoulder take-PA-1/3p | \glt `He got really bad. They stayed and stayed there and he died there. He died there and they just carried him on their shoulders.'
Content 2: \gll Ifakim-eya \textbf{pu-ep-ik-eya} om-em-ik-ua. | \gls kill-2/3s.DS die-SS.SEQ-be-2/3s.DS cry-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `When she killed him and he was dead, she was crying.'

Knowledge Point: When a topic has not been active for some time in the text, there are two main strategies to re-activate it. A personal pronoun is mainly used for the major participants. For the third person singular pronoun this is the most common usage (\sectref{sec:3.5.11}). The following example is from a text where the main participant, a man, has been killed by his spirit lover. For several sentences, the topic position is taken by the spirit woman and her parents, but in the sentence \REF{ex:9:x1921} the man, as a re-activated topic, gets up and goes to his village.
Content 1: \gll Epa wiim-eya sawur emeria nain ikiw-eya \textbf{o} iikir-ami owowa ekap-o-k. | \gls place dawn-2/3s.DS spirit woman that1 go-2/3s.DS 3s.UNM get.up-SS.SIM village come-PA-3s | \glt `It dawned and the spirit woman went, and he got up and came to the village.'

Knowledge Point: The sentence in \REF{ex:9:x1923} re-activates the topic, a grandmother and two grandchildren, after a gap of five clauses:
Content 1: \gll Iwera mekemkar-ep or-eya \textbf{wi} pikin-ep miiwa or-o-mik. | \gls coconut bend-SS.SEQ descend-2/3s.DS 3p.UNM jump-SS.SEQ ground descend-PA-1/3p | \glt `The coconut tree bent down and they jumped down to the ground.'

Knowledge Point: In the following stretch, \REF{ex:9:x1924}, the health officer, who is one of the main participants in this section of the story, is mentioned as an object noun phrase, and after two clauses he becomes the topic for just one clause. Afterwards, the men accompanying the sick man again resume as the topic.
Content 1: \gll ...ikemika kaik-owa mua nain nop-a-mik, imen-ap maak-iwkin \textbf{o} miim-o-k. Aria, \textbf{wi} kiiriw neeke {\O} miiw-aasa um-o-k. | \gls wound tie-NMZ man that1 search-PA-1/3p find-SS.SEQ tell-2/3p.DS 3s.UNM precede-PA-3s alright 3p.UNM again there.CF {\O} land-canoe die-PA-3s | \glt `{\dots} they searched for the health officer, and when they found him and told him, he went ahead of them (to the aidpost). Alright, again when they were there the truck broke down.'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:9:x1677} is an extract from a story about the speaker's uncle, who was introduced with a kinship term at the very beginning of the story and only referred to by a verbal suffix or an occasional pronoun afterwards. An important prop, snake poison, which becomes a topic for a short stretch, is referred to by a full noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll Akia ik-ep en-em-ik-ok \textbf{ifa} \textbf{marasin} \textbf{nain=ke} kema wiar iw-a-k. Iw-aya nan miira saawirin-e-k. Ne auwa ame wia maak-eya res aaw-ep merena ... nain puuk-a-mik. Puuk-ap marasin wu-om-a-mik. Marasin wu-om-a-mik=na weetak. Iiriw \textbf{ifa} \textbf{marasin=ke} kekan-e-k. Ne akia ik-e-k nain me en-e-k. Nan mukuna=pa ik-eya o nan samor aaw-o-k. | \gls banana roast-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SIM.be-SS snake poison that1=CF liver 3.DAT go-PA-3s go-2/3s.DS there face become.round-PA-3s ADD 1s/p.father ASS 3p.ACC tell-2/3s.DS razor take-SS.SEQ leg ... that1 cut-PA-1/3p cut-SS.SEQ medicine put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p medicine put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p=TP no earlier snake poison=CF be.strong-PA-3s ADD banana roast-PA-3s that1 not eat-PA-3s there fire=LOC be-2/3s.DS 3s.UNM there badly get-PA-3s | \glt `He roasted bananas and when he was eating them the snake poison entered his liver. It entered and he felt dizzy there. And when he told my father and others, they took a razor and made a cut into the leg{\dots} They made a cut and put medicine into it. They put medicine but no (it didn't help). The snake poison was already strong. And he didn't eat the bananas that he roasted. They were there on the fire and he really got bad there.'

Knowledge Point: The topic marker -(\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e})\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} (\sectref{sec:3.12.7.1}) is only used with a new topic that the speaker wants to highlight. The constituent may have been briefly mentioned in an earlier clause \REF{ex:9:x1680}, \REF{ex:9:x1678}, or it is known from the outset as a future topic \REF{ex:9:x1679}, and now it is specified as the topic for the following section of text.
Content 1: \gll Mauw-owa kamenap nain on-a-man? \textbf{Mauw-owa}\textbf{=na} sira yia nokar-e-mik, yiena kae sira nain. | \gls work-NMZ what.like that1 do-PA-2p work-NMZ=TP custom 1p.ACC ask-PA-1/3p 1p.GEN 1s/p.grandfather custom that1 | \glt `What kind of work did you do? - The work (was such that) they asked us about customs, our ancestral customs.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Yo efa aaw-eya i owawiya ik-omkun \textbf{Yaapan}\textbf{=ena} Wewak kame=pa nan ir-a-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.ACC take-2/3s.DS 1p.UNM together be-1s/p.DS Japan=TP Wewak side=LOC there come-PA-1/3p | \glt `He married me, and while we were together the Japanese came from the Wewak side.'

Knowledge Point: Highlighted topics are more frequent in conversations than in narratives. Since the first and second persons are more topical than the third person \REF{ex:9:x1684}, \REF{ex:9:x1685}, they may even get marked as topic when the discussion itself is about something else \REF{ex:9:x1686}. The second person singular pronoun with the topic marker, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nos-na,} has acquired the meaning somewhat like `you know' in English \REF{ex:9:x1687}. A highlighted topic of this kind need not be a constituent in a clause.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nos=na}? | \gls 2s.FC=TP | \glt `What about you?' or: `What do you want?' or: `Where are you going?'
Content 2: \gll Emar, \textbf{yos=na} amina=ke weetak. | \gls friend 1s.FC=TP saucepan=CF no | \glt `Friend, I do not have a saucepan.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Is}\textbf{=na} yoo, takira fain ifa=ke ku-eya akua aaw-ep ekap-em-ika-i-mik yoo! | \gls 1p.FC=TP INTJ boy this snake=CF bite-2/3s.DS shoulder take-SS.SEQ come-SS.SIM-be-NP-PR.1/3p INTJ | \glt `We - this boy was bitten by a snake and we are coming carrying him on our shoulders.'
Content 4: \gll Mauwa ar-e-n, amia=iya nenar-e-mik=i? -Wia, \textbf{nos=na}, yo fiker fufa iw-ap nefa far-i-yem. | \gls what become-PA-2s bow=COM shoot.you-PA-1/3p=QM No 2s.FC=TP 1s.UNM kunai.grass base go-SS.SEQ 2s.ACC call-NP-PR.1s | \glt `What happened to you, did they shoot you with a gun? -No, you know, I went inside the kunai grass and am calling you.'

Knowledge Point: The contrastive focus marker in Mauwake is -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke}, which cliticizes to a noun phrase (\sectref{sec:3.12.7.2}). It can also follow a temporal or location word, although this is rare. The domain of the contrastive focus is one constituent. It is used when the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} is in focus and is contrasted with something else \REF{ex:9:x1688}, \REF{ex:9:x1689}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Os=ke} ikiw-o-k. | \gls 3s.FC=CF go-PA-3s | \glt `It was he who went.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{bug} \textbf{maala} \textbf{nain}\textbf{=ke} mera unowa isak-i-non, mua bug iiwa nain weetak. | \gls man wind long that1=CF fish many spear-NP-FI.3s man wind short that1 no | \glt `A man with big lungs will spear many fish, a man with small lungs no.´

Knowledge Point: Sometimes the use or non-use of the contrastive marker makes a difference in the interpretation of the meaning of a word. In \REF{ex:9:x1690}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} `big' refers to the size of the man as a neutral quality, but in \REF{ex:9:x1691} either his big size is contrasted with the size of other people, or he is set apart as one of a limited set of big men, i.e., chiefs.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain maneka. | \gls man that1 big | \glt `That man is big.'
Content 2: \gll Mua nain \textbf{maneka=ke}. | \gls man that1 big=CF | \gls \glt `That man is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{BIG}' or: `That man is a big man/chief.'

Knowledge Point: The main position for the contrastive focus marking is the subject \REF{ex:9:x1688},\footnote{Waskia has an identical morpheme ke, labeled as a subject marker \citep[36]{RossEtAl1978}%Paol
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Os=ke} ikiw-o-k. | \gls 3s.FC=CF go-PA-3s | \glt `It was he who went.'

Knowledge Point: . The examples cited are very similar to those cases in Mauwake where the contrastive focus marker cliticizes to the subject.} \REF{ex:9:x1689}, or the non-verbal predicate of a verbless clause \REF{ex:9:x1691}. In a few cases, some other constituent is marked, e.g., a contrasted object \REF{ex:9:x1692}, \REF{ex:9:x1697} or an adverbial phrase \REF{ex:9:x1693}, \REF{ex:9:x1694}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{bug} \textbf{maala} \textbf{nain}\textbf{=ke} mera unowa isak-i-non, mua bug iiwa nain weetak. | \gls man wind long that1=CF fish many spear-NP-FI.3s man wind short that1 no | \glt `A man with big lungs will spear many fish, a man with small lungs no.´
Content 2: \gll Mua nain \textbf{maneka=ke}. | \gls man that1 big=CF | \gls \glt `That man is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{BIG}' or: `That man is a big man/chief.'
Content 3: \gll Ne \textbf{erepam} \textbf{nain=ke} wiena skul stua on-a-mik. | \gls ADD four that1=CF 3p.GEN school store make-PA-1/3p | \glt `And the fourth one they made into their school store.'
Content 4: \gll Maa en-owa iw-e-mik, \textbf{rais=ke} weetak. | \gls food eat-NMZ give.him-PA-1/3p rice=CF no | \glt `They gave him food (root crops), but not rice.'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Amirika}\textbf{=ke} eliw ika-i-yem, \textbf{uura=ke} napum-ar-i-yem. | \gls noon=CF well be-NP-PR.1s night=CF sick-INCH-NP-PR.1s | \glt `At noon I am well, at night I am sick.'
Content 6: \gll \textbf{Amiten}\textbf{=ke} ikiw-i-yem, \textbf{Susure=ke} me ikiw-i-yem. | \gls Amiten=CF go-NP-PR.1s Susure=CF not go-NP-PR.1s | \glt `I go to Amiten but I don't go to Susure.'

Knowledge Point: The contrastive focus marker is also used for subject disambiguation. When an object of a clause is fronted as the theme, the constituent order changes from \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{sov}} to \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{osv}}. If both the subject and object are in the third person and are realized as overt \textsc{np}s, this creates a potential ambiguity as to which one is which argument. The contrastive focus marker, added to the subject, may first have been used to disambiguate clauses like \REF{ex:9:x1695} and later spread as an optional marking even to clauses where the verbal suffix distinguishes the two arguments and which would not need this extra marking \REF{ex:9:x1696}. Without the contrastive focus marking, the example \REF{ex:9:x1695} would mean `and my younger sibling got/took an arrow/a bullet'.
Content 1: \gll Ne yena aamun \textbf{ariwa=ke} aaw-o-k. | \gls ADD 1s.GEN 1s/p.younger.sibling arrow=CF get-PA-3s | \glt `And my younger sibling was killed by a bullet (lit: arrow).'
Content 2: \gll Fofa=pa maa mauwa on-i-mik nain (\textbf{yos=ke}) ma-i-yem. | \gls market=LOC thing what do-NP-PR.1/3p that1 1s.FC=CF say-NP-PR.1s | \glt `I tell what we do at the market.'
Content 3: \gll Ne yena aamun \textbf{ariwa=ke} aaw-o-k. | \gls ADD 1s.GEN 1s/p.younger.sibling arrow=CF get-PA-3s | \glt `And my younger sibling was killed by a bullet (lit: arrow).'

Knowledge Point: Although the contrastive focus marker is very common when both the subject and object in an \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{osv}} clause are \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}}s, it is not obligatory. See the second clause of \REF{ex:9:x1702} for an example.
Content 1: \gll Naap ik-ok wi Saramun=ke wiisa uf-e-mik. \textbf{Uf-owa} \textbf{eliwa}\textsubscript{O} i wiar uruf-a-mik. | \gls thus be-SS 3p.UNM Saramun=CF dance.name dance-PA-1/3p dance-NMZ good 1p.UNM 3.DAT see-PA-1/3p | \glt `Then the Saramun people danced wiisa. It was a good dance we saw from them.'

Knowledge Point: In other situations where there is ambiguity about the subject, the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{cf}} marker is also used. If \REF{ex:9:x1705} did not have \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{cf}} marking, Pita could be interpreted as the possessor of the betelnuts and so the meaning would be `He stole Pita's betelnuts from me'.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:x1706}, the second \textstyleAcronymallcaps{cf} is necessary, because otherwise `this other one' would be interpreted as an object; the real object in the second clause is marked by zero.
Content 1: \gll Ikoka \textbf{masin} \textbf{kaanin=ke} samor-ar-eya \textbf{oko} \textbf{fain=ke} asip-i-non. | \gls later engine which=CF bad-INCH-2/3s.DS other this=CF help-NP-FU.3s | \glt `Later when any of the engines breaks this other one will help it.'

Knowledge Point: A clause can only have one constituent with contrastive focus. In a verbless clause, either the subject \REF{ex:9:x1708} or the non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:9:x1707} can be marked with it, but not both.
Content 1: \gll Wia, \textbf{yos=ke} owow saria ika-i-yem. | \gls no 1s.FC=CF village headman be-NP-PR.1s | \glt `No, I am the village headman.'
Content 2: \gll Yo \textbf{owow(a)} \textbf{saria=ke}. | \gls 1s.UNM village headman=CF | \glt `I am the village headman.'

Knowledge Point: Contrastive focus can be assigned to a constituent regardless of whether it is given or new \REF{ex:9:x1709}, indefinite \REF{ex:9:x1710} or definite \REF{ex:9:x1711}. Non-verbal predicates with \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textup{\textsc{cf}}} are mostly new information, whereas for subjects neither givenness nor definiteness matters.
Content 1: \gll Iperuma nain me enim-eka, \textbf{inasin} \textbf{mua=ke}. | \gls eel that1 not eat-IMP.2p spirit man=CF | \glt `Don't eat the eel, it is a spirit man.'
Content 2: \gll Iir oko \textbf{mua} \textbf{oko=ke} koora ku-ek-a-m na-ep maakara war-ep{\dots} | \gls time other man other=CF house build-CNTF-PA-1s say-SS.SEQ timber cut-SS.SEQ | \glt `Another time a man wanted to build a house and he cut timber and {\dots}'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Aaya} \textbf{nain=ke} ifa puuk-a-k. | \gls sugarcane that1=CF snake change.into-PA-3s | \glt `The sugarcane changed into a snake.'

Knowledge Point: In non-polar questions, it is the questioned element that is in focus. This is reflected in the question words and in the answers. When the question word is the subject \REF{ex:9:x1714} or the non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:9:x1712}, it takes the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{cf}} clitic, and the corresponding constituent in the answer usually gets the focus marking as well \REF{ex:9:x1715}, \REF{ex:9:x1713}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{naareke} nefa maak-e-k? | \gls man who.CF 2s.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt `Who told you?'
Content 2: \gll Maa nain \textbf{mauwa=ke}? | \gls thing that1 what=CF | \glt `What is that thing?'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mua}\textbf{=ke} me efa maak-e-mik, yena mokok=iw uruf-a-m. | \gls man=CF not 1s.ACC tell-PA-1/3p 1s.GEN eye=INST see-PA-1s | \glt `It wasn't people that told me, I saw it with my own eyes.'
Content 4: \gll Maa nain \textbf{posa=ke}. | \gls thing that1 turban.shell=CF | \glt `That thing is a turban shell.'

Knowledge Point: The contrastive focus clitic and the question clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} merge into -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ki} when both are used with the same constituent. This happens when the non-verbal predicate of a verbless clause is questioned \REF{ex:9:x1716}, in alternative questions \REF{ex:9:x1718}, and sometimes in alternative statements \REF{ex:9:x1717}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria fain \textbf{Eema=ki}? | \gls woman this Eema=CF.QM | \glt `Is this woman Eema?'
Content 2: \gll Emeria fain \textbf{Eema=ki} e \textbf{emeria} \textbf{oko=ke?} | \gls woman this Eema=CF.QM or woman other=CF | \glt `Is this woman Eema or another woman?'

Knowledge Point: The neutral focus clitic (\sectref{sec:3.12.7.2}) most commonly occurs in irrealis-type clauses, i.e., questions \REF{ex:9:x1719}, commands \REF{ex:9:x1720}, negated clauses \REF{ex:9:x1721} or those with future tense \REF{ex:9:x1722}, hence its original name in \citet{Jarvinen1988b}. But it is also used in a some realis-type clauses. Although the clitic has probably developed from the indefinite \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oko} `a (certain), (an)other', it is added to definite noun phrases as well.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aaya}\textbf{=ko} niar ik-ua=i? | \gls sugar=NF 2p.DAT be-PA.3s=QM | \gls \glt `Do you have (ANY) SUGAR?'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Owowa} \textbf{oko=ko} me uf-e-mik. | \gls village other=NF not dance-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `OTHER VILLAGES did not dance.'
Content 4: \gll Yo aakisa \textbf{opaimika=ko} ma-i-nen. | \gls 1s.UNM now talk/story=NF say-NP-FU.1s | \gls \glt `Now I will tell A STORY.'

Knowledge Point: In most of those few instances where the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} clitic marks a constituent in a clearly realis-type clause, that constituent is a new, indefinite \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} introduced as a subject \REF{ex:9:x1733}, \REF{ex:9:x1732}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Nan iimar-ep ika-eya \textbf{urema=ko} ekap-eya miim-a-k. | \gls there stand.up-SS.SEQ be-2/3s.DS bandicoot=NF come-2/3s.DS hear-PA-3s | \gls \glt `He was standing there and he heard A BANDICOOT coming.' (Lit: `{\dots}a bandicoot came and he heard it').

Knowledge Point: Any constituent in a clause can be marked as focused with the neutral focus clitic. The subject \REF{ex:9:x1733} and object \REF{ex:9:x1722} have been exemplified above, but a recipient \REF{ex:9:x1723}, adverbial \REF{ex:9:x1724}, \REF{ex:9:x1730}, comitative, \REF{ex:9:x1725} and instrument \REF{ex:9:x1726} are also possible:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Yo aakisa \textbf{opaimika=ko} ma-i-nen. | \gls 1s.UNM now talk/story=NF say-NP-FU.1s | \gls \glt `Now I will tell A STORY.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{nain=ko} onak-e. | \gls man that1=NF feed.him-IMP.1s | \gls \glt `Give it to THAT MAN to eat.'
Content 4: \gll Miiw-aasa \textbf{era=pa=ko} me yiar samor-ar-e-k. | \gls land-canoe road=LOC=NF not 1p.DAT bad-INCH-PA-3s | \gls \glt `Our truck did not break ON THE ROAD.'
Content 5: \gll Ne \textbf{samor} \textbf{akena=ko} aruf-a-mik. | \gls ADD badly very=NF hit-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `And they beat him VERY BADLY.'
Content 7: \gll \textbf{Fura}\textbf{=iw=ko} me puuk-a-mik. | \gls knife=INST=NF not cut-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `They didn't cut it WITH A KNIFE.'

Knowledge Point: In a sentence the final, fully inflected verbs are already on the basis of their position more prominent than other verbs, and they cannot receive focus marking. But the medial verbs may be given extra prominence with the neutral focus clitic \REF{ex:9:x1727}.
Content 1: \gll Amerika kerer-e-mik na-i-ya, \textbf{ikiw-ep=ko} wia uruf-ik-ua. | \gls America appear-PA-1/3p say-NP-PR.3s go-SS.SEQ=NF 3p.ACC see-be-PA.3s | \gls \glt `He says that the Americans have arrived, let's GO and see them.'

Knowledge Point: Even the verbal negation particle \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not' can be marked with the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} clitic, in which case the focus is on negating the whole proposition \REF{ex:9:x1728}.
Content 1: \gll Takira \textbf{me=ko} wia aruf-a-mik. | \gls boy not=NF 3p.ACC hit-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `It is NOT the case that we hit the boys.'

Knowledge Point: A clause can only have one contrastive focus,\footnote{Clauses with a locative adverb neeke or feeke (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}) are an exception.} but negations and especially polite requests may contain two or even three constituents marked with the neutral focus \REF{ex:9:x1729}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{No=ko} \textbf{era=ko} \textbf{imen-ap=ko} yia asip-e. | \gls 2s.UNM=NF way=NF find-SS.SEQ=NF 1p.ACC help-IMP.2s | \glt `If you find a way, please help us.' Or: `Please find a way to help us.'

Knowledge Point: Especially in spoken language, it is possible to reduplicate the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} clitic in a word for extra prominence \REF{ex:9:x1731}.
Content 1: \gll Wi kema ma-e-mik, ``\textbf{O=ko=ko} amukar-ek-a-n nom. Moram me amukar-e-n?'' | \gls 3p.UNM liver say-PA-1/3p 3s.UNM=NF=NF scold-CNTF-PA-2s please why not scold-PA-2s | \gls \glt `They said in their hearts, ``C'mon, you should have scolded \textstyleEmphasizedWords{HIM}. Why didn't you scold him?'' '

Knowledge Point: The two focus markers are not mutually exclusive, and consequently they can co-occur in one clause \REF{ex:9:x1737}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yos=ke} \textbf{maa} \textbf{nain=ko} me aaw-e-m. | \gls 1s.FC=CF thing that1=NF not take-PA-1s | \glt `It wasn't I who took that thing.'

Knowledge Point: The constituent with focus marking retains the same position in a clause that it has in a non-focused clause. When a personal pronoun in some other case than nominative receives neutral focus, an unmarked pronoun is added as a pronoun copy and marked with the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} clitic \REF{ex:9:x1743}. When this pronoun gets fronted as a theme, it is the pronoun copy that is fronted \REF{ex:9:x1744}.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain \textbf{i=ko} me \textbf{yia} far-e-k. | \gls man that1 1p.UNM=NF not 1p.ACC call-PA-3s | \gls \glt `The man didn't call US.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I}\textbf{=ko} mua nain-(ke) me \textbf{yia} far-e-k. | \gls 1p.UNM=NF man that1-(CF) not 1p.ACC call-PA-3s | \gls \glt `\TEXTSC{US} the man didn't call.'

Knowledge Point: More research is needed in order to establish what kind of prominence the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} clitic marks. Of the following three examples, \REF{ex:9:x1734} is a low-prominence clause with no item marked for extra prominence, in \REF{ex:9:x1735} `I' is contrasted with other people, and in \REF{ex:9:x1736} the prominence is neutral: the speaker emphasizes that (s)he didn't see, but there is no implied contrast.
Content 1: \gll Yo me uruf-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM not see-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't see it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yos}\textbf{=ke} me uruf-a-m. | \gls 1s.FC=CF not see-PA-1s | \glt `It wasn't I who saw it (but someone else).'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Yo}\textbf{=ko} me uruf-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM=NF not see-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't see it (regardless of whether anyone else did or not)'

Knowledge Point: Introduction of an indefinite topic has already been mentioned as one of the functions of neutral focus. In questions and requests the focus marking indicates politeness. And especially in many negated clauses with \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{nf}} marking, there is a sense of distancing oneself from the situation \REF{ex:9:x1738}.
Content 1: \gll I \textbf{mua=ko} me wia furew-a-mik ne yiena pun \textbf{mukuna}\textbf{=ko} me op-a-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM man=NF not 3p.ACC sense-PA-1/3p ADD 1p.GEN also fire=NF not hold-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `We didn't sense (ANY) PEOPLE (there) and we ourselves didn't carry fire either.'

Knowledge Point: Cross-linguistically, the most common focusing device is possibly stress. Stress in Mauwake is not only a word-level feature (\sectref{sec:2.1.3.1}); it can be employed to give prominence to a word or phrase in a clause. Default, or neutral, clause stress is on the verb or the non-verbal predicate. An extra heavy stress is used for contrastive focus especially for those constituents that seldom or never take \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{cf}} marking \REF{ex:9:x1739}--\REF{ex:9:x1742}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{O}\textbf{{{\textprimstress}}}\textbf{wowa=pa} emeria unowa wia maak-e-mik. | \gls village=LOC woman many 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `IN THE VILLAGE they told it to many women.'
Content 2: \gll Owowa=pa emeria unowa wia \textbf{{{\textprimstress}}}\textbf{maak-e-mik}. | \gls village=LOC woman many 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `In the village they \textstyleEmphasizedWords{TOLD} it to many women (instead of hiding it from them).'

Knowledge Point: Note that in \REF{ex:9:x1742} it is only the loudness/intensity in the stressed word that distinguishes it from the neutral clausal stress.
Content 1: \gll Owowa=pa emeria unowa wia \textbf{{{\textprimstress}}}\textbf{maak-e-mik}. | \gls village=LOC woman many 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p | \gls \glt `In the village they \textstyleEmphasizedWords{TOLD} it to many women (instead of hiding it from them).'

Knowledge Point: Right-dislocation is often called a topicalizing device, but in Mauwake it can't be that, since only a few of the right-dislocated constituents are topics \REF{ex:9:x1745}.
Content 1: \gll Maa nain aaw-ep iima=pa wu-om-ap om-em-ik-ua, \textbf{sawur} \textbf{emeria} \textbf{nain}\textbf{=ke}. | \gls thing that1 take-SS.SEQ chest=LOC put-BEN-BNFY2.SS.SEQ cry-SS.SIM-be-3s.PA spirit woman that1=CF | \glt `She took the thing and put it on his chest, the spirit woman (did).'

Knowledge Point: Most of the right-dislocated elements are not topics. Right-dislocation seems to be a focusing device of a special kind: the speaker decides that some constituent needs clarification or more prominence than it received, and adds it as an afterthought after the clause \REF{ex:9:x1746}--\REF{ex:9:x1748}.
Content 1: \gll Saapara=pa nan suusa iw-e-mik, \textbf{wiena} \textbf{ifa} \textbf{suusa} \textbf{nain}. | \gls Saapara=LOC there needle give.him-PA-1/3p 3p.GEN snake needle that1 | \glt `There in Saapara they gave him an injection, their snake (antivenene) injection.'
Content 2: \gll Ne fraide=pa maapora puk-o-k, \textbf{urera}. | \gls ADD Friday=LOC party burst-PA-3s afternoon | \glt `And on Friday the party started, in the afternoon.'
